cards.title: Lines
cards.subtitle: parallel, perpendicular, neither
cards.desc: Parallel lines never intersect, perpendicular lines intersect at 90°, all other lines intersect at some other angle

cards.title: Intersecting Lines
cards.subtitle: Neither parallel nor perpendicular
cards.desc: Lines that intersect that are not parallel or perpendicular are considered neither or simply intersecting

cards.title: Correlation coefficient
cards.subtitle: Doesn't necessarily indicate causation!
cards.desc: A number between −1 and +1 calculated so as to represent the linear dependence of two variables or sets of data. Numbers closer to each extreme indicate greater correlation.

cards.title: Perpendicular
cards.subtitle: Perpendicular lines form right angles
cards.desc: Perpendicular lines intersect at 90&#176

cards.title: Axis of symmetry
cards.subtitle: It is a vertical line with the equation of x = -b/2a.
cards.desc: It is the line of symmetry of a parabola and divides a parabola into two equal halves that are reflections of each other about the line of symmetry- it intersects a parabola at its vertex

cards.title: Parallel
cards.subtitle: They'll never intersect!
cards.desc: Parallel lines are two straight lines that continue in the same direction but never intersect.

cards.title: No Solution Equation
cards.subtitle: An equation that does not have a mathematic solution
cards.desc: A no solution equation is an equation that has two sides that cannot ever be equivalent, meaning that the variable in the equation is either an imaginary number or is not feasible.

cards.title: Circle
cards.subtitle: A one-sided or infinite-sided polygon?
cards.desc: The set of all points equidistant to a fixed point, called the center

cards.title: Radius
cards.subtitle: They're all equal
cards.desc: Segment (or length of the segment) from center of circle to the circle's edge

cards.title: Circumference
cards.subtitle: 2π(r) for the win!
cards.desc: Distance around a circle. C = 2r(π) or C = d(π)

cards.title: Area of a circle
cards.subtitle: think inside the circle.
cards.desc: Amount of plane space within the boundary of the circle. A = r<sup>2</sup>(π)

cards.title: Acute triangles
cards.subtitle: ... are cute
cards.desc: All three angles in a triangle measure less than 90°

cards.title: Obtuse triangles
cards.subtitle: ... are obese (no offense!)
cards.desc: One angle in a triangle measures greater than 90°

cards.title: Right triangles
cards.subtitle: ... can sit upright!
cards.desc: One angle in a triangle measures 90°

cards.title: Central angle
cards.subtitle: a central angle equals its arc.
cards.desc: An angle whose vertex is the center of a circle and sides are radii.

cards.title: Equilateral triangles
cards.subtitle: a 'regular' triangle
cards.desc: A three-sided figure with all sides congruent and angles congruent

cards.title: Vertical angles
cards.subtitle: ... are always congruent to one another
cards.desc: Each of the pairs of opposite angles made by two intersecting lines

cards.title: Line of best fit
cards.subtitle: 'The best fitting line' for a set of data
cards.desc: Straight line that best represents the data on a scatter plot

cards.title: Perimeter
cards.subtitle: Triangles, Quadrilaterals, Polygons
cards.desc: The continuous line forming the boundary of a closed geometric figure. To find perimeter you have to add up the lengths of all sides of the polygon.

cards.title: Pythagorean theorem
cards.subtitle: a&sup2 + b&sup2 = c&sup2
cards.desc: The equation which determines the relation between the side lengths of a right triangle.

cards.title: Area of a trapezoid
cards.subtitle: amount of space a 2-D object takes up
cards.desc: (base<sub>1</sub> + base<sub>2</sub>)/2)(height)

cards.title: Area of a parallelogram
cards.subtitle: amount of space a 2-D object takes up
cards.desc: base * height

cards.title: Area of a rhombus
cards.subtitle: amount of space a 2-D object takes up
cards.desc: base*height or (diagonal<sub>1</sub> * diagonal<sub>2</sub>)/2

cards.title: Squares
cards.subtitle: A special member of the quadrilateral family
cards.desc: A four-sided plane (2D) figure with four equal sides with four right angles

cards.title: Parallelogram
cards.subtitle: a special member of the quadrilateral family
cards.desc: A four-sided plane (2D) figure with both pairs of opposite sides parallel and congruent

cards.title: Area of a square
cards.subtitle: Base & height must be perpendicular to one another
cards.desc: Area = base*height

cards.title: Angle sum of a triangle
cards.subtitle: The three angles of a triangle add to 180°
cards.desc: In a Euclidean space, the sum of measures of these three angles of any triangle is invariably equal to the straight angle, also expressed as 180°, π radians, two right angles, or a half-turn..

cards.title: Other Polygons
cards.subtitle: pentagons, hexagons, septagons(heptagon), etc
cards.desc: pentagons = 5 sides, hexagons = 6 sides, septagons/heptagon = 7 sides, octagon = 8 sides, nonagon = 9 sides, Decagon = 10 sides, Hendegon = 11 sides, Dodecagon = 12 sides.

cards.title: Area of a rectangle
cards.subtitle: amount of space a 2-D object takes up
cards.desc: Area = base*height or length*width

cards.title: Rhombi
cards.subtitle: a four sided shape with all four side congruent
cards.desc: Rhombus: A parallelogram with opposite equal acute angles, opposite equal obtuse angles, and four equal sides

cards.title: Rectangle
cards.subtitle: Diagonals are congruent & bisect each other
cards.desc: A four-sided plane (2D) figure with opposite sides parallel and congruent, and four right angles. All squares are rectangles, not all rectangles are squares!

cards.title: Kites
cards.subtitle: ... go fly one!
cards.desc: A four-sided plane (2D) figure with adjacent sides congruent

cards.title: Trapezoids
cards.subtitle: A member of the quadrilateral family
cards.desc: A four-sided plane (2D) figure with at least one pair of opposite sides parallel to each other

cards.title: Quadratics
cards.subtitle: a curved type of function
cards.desc: Any function of the family y = x<sup>2</sup>, expressed in standard form as y = ax<sup>2</sup> + bx + c, where a ≠ 0

cards.title: Quadratic formula
cards.subtitle: Solves quadratic equations
cards.desc: The quadratic formula is used in algebra to solve quadratic equations. The general form of a quadratic equation is , where x represents a variable, and a, b, and c are constants, with a quadratic equation has two solutions, called roots.

cards.title: Slope
cards.subtitle: (y<sub>2</sub> — y<sub>1</sub>)/(x<sub>2</sub> — x<sub>1</sub>)
cards.desc: The slope of a line characterizes the steepness & direction of a line. To find the slope, you divide the difference of the y-coordinates of 2 points on a line by the difference of the x-coordinates of those same 2 points

cards.title: 2 parallel lines cut by a transversal
cards.subtitle: When two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, all of the following angle pairs are congruent:
cards.desc: corresponding, alternate interior, alternate exterior, and vertical angles

cards.title: Scatter plot
cards.subtitle: A type of graph for statistics
cards.desc: A graph of plotted points that show the relationship between two sets of data. In this example, each dot represents one person's weight versus their height.

cards.title: Chords
cards.subtitle: straight line segment, secant, diameter, ellipse
cards.desc: A straight line segment whose endpoints both lie on the circle, a chord that passes through a circle's center point is the circle's diameter. Every diameter is a chord, but not every chord is a diameter.

cards.title: Inscribed angles
cards.subtitle: An inscribed angle = half of its arc
cards.desc: An inscribed angle is an angle formed by two chords in a circle which have a common endpoint on the circle

cards.title: Positive slope
cards.subtitle: positive
cards.desc: A positive slope moves upward on a graph from left to right. When 'x' increases, 'y' also increases

cards.title: Negative slope
cards.subtitle: decreasing
cards.desc: A negative slope moves downward on a graph from left to right. When 'x' increases, 'y' decreases

cards.title: Zero slope
cards.subtitle: horizontal
cards.desc: A zero slope is just the slope of a horizontal line. The y-coordinate never changes no matter what the x-coordinate is. There is no rise.

cards.title: Undefined slope
cards.subtitle: undefined
cards.desc: An undefined slope is the slope of a vertical line. The x-coordinate never changes no matter what the y-coordinate is. There is no run.

cards.title: Zeros/Roots/x-Intercepts
cards.subtitle: to find the roots of a quadratic function, we set f (x) = 0, and solve the equation, ax<sup>2</sup> + bx + c = 0.
cards.desc: The y-coordinate of points lying on the x-axis is zero.

cards.title: Tangent
cards.subtitle: A radius and a tangent are perpendicularat the point of tangency
cards.desc: A tangent line intersects a circle at exactly one point

cards.title: Secant
cards.subtitle: Secant lines contain chords, but extend beyond the circle's boundary
cards.desc: a secant line intersects a circle at exactly two points

cards.title: Similar figures
cards.subtitle: Ratios and Proportions
cards.desc: Two figures that have the same shape and the ratios of the lenths of their corresponding sides are equal.

cards.title: Range
cards.subtitle: From min to max
cards.desc: The difference between the lowest and highest values.

cards.title: Conditional equation
cards.subtitle: Most equations are conditional—they have a finite number of solutions
cards.desc: An equation that is true for some value(s) of the variable(s) and not true for others. Example: The equation 3x - 5 = 16 is conditional because it is only true for x = 7. Other values of x do not satisfy the equation.

cards.title: Scalene triangles
cards.subtitle: Scalene ends in 'NE'—think 'none equal'
cards.desc: A triangle in which all three sides are different, resulting in angles that also vary

cards.title: Isosceles triangles
cards.subtitle: 'SOS'—think 'SAME other SAME'
cards.desc: A triangle in which two of the three sides are the same, causing the base angles to also be equal

cards.title: Plane
cards.subtitle: A two-dimensional, flat surface
cards.desc: a flat surface on which a straight line joining any two points on it would wholly lie

cards.title: Mean
cards.subtitle: The mean is the average you're used to, where you add up all the numbers and then divide by the number of numbers.
cards.desc: a calculated central value of a set of numbers

cards.title: L'Hopital's rule
cards.subtitle: When the value is indeterminate (0/0 or inf/inf)
cards.desc: Take derivatives of numer & denom, then re-evaluate

cards.title: Continuity test
cards.subtitle: A function y = f (x) is continuous at x = a if and only if the limit as x approaches a of f (x) equals f (a).
cards.desc: The following 3 conditions must hold true in order for a function to be continuous

cards.title: Second derivative test
cards.subtitle: Use to find a max or min
cards.desc: If f'(c)=0 then there is a critical point at c. If the second derivative is positive at x=c, then f has a min here. If the second derivative is negative, f has a max.

cards.title: Distance, velocity, and acceleration relationships
cards.subtitle: They all relate!
cards.desc: Velocity is the first derivative of position. Acceleration is the first derivative of velocity, or the second derivative of position. This also means that velocity is the antiderivative of acceleration and position is the antiderivative of velocity.

cards.title: Area between two curves
cards.subtitle: Top Curve Minus Bottom Curve
cards.desc: If function f(x) and g(x) and continuous and f(x)≥g(x) over the closed interval [a,b], then the area of the region between the curves f(x) and g(x) from x=a to x=b is ∫(f(x)-g(x))dx.

cards.title: Slope field
cards.subtitle: Also called vector and directional fields
cards.desc: A tool to graphically obtain the solutions to a first order differential equation. Each line segment on the slope field represents the slope at that point. The higher the derivative the steeper the slope. Horizontal lines=slope=0

cards.title: Inflection point
cards.subtitle: Use the first or second derivative!
cards.desc: An inflection point is a point on a curve at which a change in the concavity of the graph will occur. An inflection point will occur when f’’ changes signs while f’ will change direction.

cards.title: Extrema
cards.subtitle: Max and Min when f’ crosses the x axis
cards.desc: when f' changes from positive to negative there is a maximum and when f' changes from negative to positive there is a minimum

cards.title: Increasing and decreasing functions
cards.subtitle: Using the First Derivative
cards.desc: When the first derivative of a function is positive, the function is increasing. When the the first derivative is negative, the function is decreasing.

cards.title: Left rectangle approximation method
cards.subtitle: AKA LRAMs
cards.desc: A rectangle approximation, also referred to as a Riemann Sum fits one or more rectangles underneath a curve, and takes the total area of those rectangles as the estimated area beneath the curve. LRAMs are one of the methods in which the left boundary of the rectangles are used. If a function is increasing, LRAM will underestimate the area, which means the approximate area will be smaller than the actual area. If a function is decreasing, LRAM will overestimate the area, which means the approximate area will be greater than the actual area.

cards.title: Implicit differentiation
cards.subtitle: Calculus
cards.desc: Also recognized as hidden Y, implicit differentiation is solving for dy/dx within a function by taking the derivative of each term separately

cards.title: Finding total distance
cards.subtitle: Calc is fun!
cards.desc: Find total distance by integrating the velocity formula [v(t)=s'(t)] over the given interval. If the graph dips below the x-axis, you’ll need to integrate two or more parts of the graph and add the absolute values.

cards.title: Critical point
cards.subtitle: Possible extrema
cards.desc: if f is defined at x=c and either f'(c)=0 or f'(x) does not exist, then c is called a critical point

cards.title: Right Riemann sum
cards.subtitle: Rectangle approximation method
cards.desc: An approximation of the area between the function and the x-axis. If a function is increasing, RRAM overestimates the area. If a function is decreasing, RRAM underestimates the area. Given a range, you must break the area into several subintervals and use the right side of the subinterval to determine the height of a rectangle.

cards.title: Formal Limit derivative definition
cards.subtitle: Definition of the derivative
cards.desc: The derivative of the function f with respect to the variable x is the function f’, where

cards.title: Derivative rules
cards.subtitle: Product, quotient, and, chain rule
cards.desc: How to derive complicated solutions and functions

cards.title: Simple trig integral rules
cards.subtitle: Antiderivatives (Integrals) of sin(x), cos(x), and tan(x)
cards.desc: A function F(x) is an antiderivative of a function f(x) if F`(x) = f(x) for all x in the domain of f(x) . The term indefinite integral is a synonym for antiderivative.

cards.title: Concavity of a function
cards.subtitle: Concavity rules
cards.desc: If f'' (x) > 0 then f(x) is concave up.If f ''(x)<0 then f(x) is concave down

cards.title: Determining concavity
cards.subtitle: Using the first derivative to determine concavity
cards.desc: When f’(x) is increasing, f(x) is concave up. When f’(x) is decreasing,f(x) is concave down.

cards.title: Mean value theorem
cards.subtitle: MVT
cards.desc: The Mean Value Theorem states that if f(x) is differentiable and continuous on the interval [a,b], then there is at least one number c in the interval (a,b) (that is a < c < b) such that

cards.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
cards.subtitle: aka FTC for short!
cards.desc: To evaluate, the FTC says that if f is continuous on [a, b] and F is any antiderivative of f on [a, b], then . For an antiderivative, the FTC says that if f is continuous on [a, b], then the function  has a derivative at every point x in [a, b], and  .

cards.title: Displacement
cards.subtitle: there are two ways, calculus and physics
cards.desc: The positon change from point A to point B for physics, you integrate for calclulus and the area under the velocity vs.time curve

cards.title: Derivative rules
cards.subtitle: Exponential and Logarithmic Derivative Rules
cards.desc: How to take the derivative of exponential and logarithmic functions

cards.title: Calculator coding
cards.subtitle: More coding lol
cards.desc: Code for a calculator is written on the left side, the right side is what happens when you run the code applying basic math questions resulting in the code performing the action.

cards.title: Derivative rules
cards.subtitle: sin, cos, tan
cards.desc: Rules that may be followed to find several derivatives

cards.title: Volume of rotation
cards.subtitle: Washer
cards.desc: The volume of a solid is generated by revolving the region bounded by y = f(x) and y = g(x) on the interval x = a and x = b where f(x) ≥ g(x)
